Fig 5 Fig. 6 Thermogravimetry/differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) analysis of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as the new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Optimization of some parameter's reaction using MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a H-bond catalyst: a) solvent b) temperature and c) amount of catalyst. Bimetallic organic frameworks (bimetallic-MOFs) are considered promising catalysts due to their tunable pores, strength, and high catalytic performance. Here, a bimetallic-MOF-based on iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) metals was designed, synthesized and characterized. Next, the synthesized bimetallic-MOFs were post-modified with phenyl isocyanate to create urea moieties that are susceptible to hydrogen bonding (H-bond) catalytic activities. Various techniques such as SEM, XRD, BET/BJH, FT-IR, TGA/DTA, EDX and elemental-mapping were used to approve the structure of the synthesized catalyst. MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR acts as an H-bond catalyst in the multi-component reaction to form pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines via appropriate sections with medicinal properties. The features of using MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as an H-bond catalyst are increased efficiency, decreased reaction time and reusability of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Anomeric effect Anomeric based oxidation Bimetallic-organic frameworks H-bond catalyst MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR Pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction In recent years, with the progress of science and technology, the design of efficient nanoreactors with unique properties has received more attention. Porous materials have become very important because they are the basis of a lot of researches and applications [1–3]. A sub-set of porous composites, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), are known as new generation nanoreactors. These compounds are formed as porous coordinated polymers by connecting metals and organic ligands [4–7]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), like COFs and zeolites, are considered porous materials, so many research groups are focusing on this group of compounds [8,9]. Drug delivery, energy and gas storage, chemical and biological sensors, water purification, catalysts and photocatalysts are applications of MOFs [10–15]. Applications of MOFs have found various applications due to their high surface area, high porosity, multiple affinity, crystallinity and tunable topography, easy synthesis, high thermal and chemical stability [16,17]. The applications of MOF are due to high surface area, high porosity, multiple affinity, adjustable crystallinity and topography, easy synthesis, high thermal and chemical stability, which has given a new insight into this type of porous materials. Recently, the use of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) containing two metals has found wide applications which are known as bimetallic-MOFs [18–20]. Studies have shown that in this category of catalysts, the two metals present in the MOF structure cause a synergistic effect [21]. Enhanced catalytic selectivity, performance, and stability can be achieved through suitable metal selection [22,23]. There are two methods in one category to synthesize bimetallic organic frameworks (bimetallic-MOFs). In the first method, two selected metals are mixed with organic ligands to synthesize bimetallic-MOFs. The second method replaces the metal in prefabricated MOFs [24–26]. This property of metal-organic framework makes this class of porous catalysts superior to other porous catalysts such as mesoporous silica, zeolites and porous carbons [27,28]. Considering the designable properties of MOFs, our research group has used these compounds as heterogeneous porous catalysts with acidic, basic and hydrogen bonding properties in various reactions [29–38]. In recent years, the use of modified heterogeneous catalysts with organic compounds such as urea and thiourea as hydrogen-bonding catalysts has been developed [36,39]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent-organic frameworks (COFs), and amorphous porous organic polymers (POPs) are three groups of heterogeneous catalysts that have been used as hydrogen-bonding catalysts in a variety of reactions [40–42]. Research results have shown that metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) modified with urea and thiourea groups, which act as hydrogen-bonding catalysts, can catalyze the synthesis of organic compounds under mild conditions [36,39]. Catalysts based on hydrogen bonding have high selectivity and this ability has improved their catalytic properties because in this case, they can play both an acidic and a basic role. Pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines are a class of heterocyclic compounds that consist of a pyrazole moiety fused to a quinoline ring. They have been found to exhibit a wide range of biological activities, including antitumor, antiviral, and anti-inflammatory properties. Pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines have also been investigated as potential therapeutic agents for various diseases such as cancer, Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases [43,44]. Compounds with henna, indole, and pyrazole skeletons, have especially biological and medicinal properties (Fig. S1, see in ESI) [45–47]. Due to the above-mentioned fact, herein we used henna, indole and pyrazole as starting materials in the presence of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, as a hydrogen-bond catalyst, for preparing a new category of benzo[g]pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline-5,10-diones compounds. Overall, these heterocyclic compounds represent a diverse class of molecules with significant potential in medicinal chemistry. Anomeric effect (AE) as a subset of stereoelectronic effects affects the structure and reactivity of organic compounds [48,49]. The anomeric effect (AE) is another name of negative hyperconjugation. The concept anomeric effect (AE) plays an important role in chemical processes and especially organic reactions. Anomeric effect (AE) has an amazing ability to support chemical reactions, through the lone pair electrons sharing of nitrogen atom into the anti-bonding orbitals of C-H bond (nN→σ*C-H). The mentioned process has been named “anomeric based oxidation” (ABO) [50–52]. Yarie has been mini-reviewed “geminal and vinylogous anomeric based oxidation” [53,54]. Oxidation based on the anomeric effect serves to oxidize compounds without the presence of an oxidizing agent. The anomeric effect can also be exerted across double bonds, known as a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation. Our research group has developed this concept in the synthesis of various heterocyclic compounds (Fig. S2, see in ESI). The application of metal-organic frameworks, especially bimetallic-MOFs, has been shown as an important group of porous compounds in the field of catalysis. Considering the properties of these materials as well as the importance of H-bond catalysts, it led us to design a porous heterogeneous structure based on a bimetallic-MOFs with urea functional groups. The simultaneous presence of two dissimilar metals (Fe & Co) in the structure and placement of urea on it creates a suitable structure that increases its catalytic efficiency. The catalytic application of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR in the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines was investigated to prove the ability of desired catalyst. Experimental section Materials and methods Indole (C8H7N, 99%), acetic anhydride (C4H6O3, 95%), cyano acetic acid (C3H3NO2, 99%), hydrazine (N2H4, 80%), phenyl hydrazine (C6H8N2, 97%), P-TSA (C7H8O3S, 99%), 2‑hydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone (Henna, 98%), Co(NO3)3∙6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), FeCl3∙6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), 2-amino terephthalic acid (NH2-BDC, 95%), phenyl isocyanate (PhNCO, 98%) and various aromatic aldehyde derivatives (95%) were purchased from Merck and Sigma-Aldrich. Furthermore, N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%), ethanol (EtOH, 99%), methanol (MeOH, 99%), acetonitrile (CH3CN, 99%) and other solvents were purchased from commercial sources without further purification. Characterization The X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD) technique with a model device PHILIPS PW1730 (Netherlands), was used to characterize the crystal plates of the catalyst. The FT-IR technique model device (PerkinElmer Spectrum Version 10.02.00) was used to identify the functional groups of the different stages of the catalyst. Moreover, the morphology of the different stages of catalyst was characterized using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) technique as well as energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and elemental mapping was carried out by the model ZEISS Sigma VP (German). In addition, the thermal and chemical stability of the catalyst was determined using a thermogravimetry/differential thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) technique (BAHR STA 503). Finally, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, BELSORP-mini-II) British Journal of Haematology (BJH) technique with a model device BELSORP-mini-II was utilized to determine the surface area and pore size of the synthesized catalyst. The required precursors were synthesized according to our recently reported educational theory [55]. Preparation of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 was synthesized according to a previously described method [56]. For this purpose, BDC-NH2 (2 mmol, 0.362 g) was dissolved in 7.5 mL of DMF (Solution A). Then, in a 10 mL bottom flask, Co(NO3)3∙6H2O (0.66 mmol, 0.192 g) and FeCl3∙6H2O (1.33 mmol, 0.359 g) were dissolved in 7.5 mL DMF (Solution B). Next, solution A was added to solution B and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. After this time, the contents were transferred to Teflon-autoclave and held at 120 °C for 24 h. The resulting precipitate was washed several times with DMF & MeOH and then dried at 90 °C to give a brown precipitate of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 (Scheme 1). Preparation of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst To synthesize MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, 0.2 g of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 was dispersed in 10 mL of acetonitrile (CH3CN) as a solvent. In the next step, phenyl isocyanate (5 mmol, 0.596 g) was added to the mixture dispersing of bimetallic-MOF. Then the contents were transferred to Teflon-autoclave and exposed to a temperature of 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the precipitate was washed several times with CH3CN and dried at 80 °C to achieved MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst (Scheme 1). The structure of the MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR was confirmed using 13C NMR. (details provided in the ESI). Catalytic reaction After preparing MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous H-bond catalyst, this catalyst was used in the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines with pyrazolo, Henna and indole moieties. According to the previous reports, starting marerial such as 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine and 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-3-amine has been synthesized [57]. A quantity of the main raw material (1 mmol), aldehyde derivative (1 mmol) and henna (1 mmol) were transferred to a 10 mL round-bottom flask. Then 0.01 g of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a catalyst and 5 mL of EtOH were added to the reaction vessel. The reaction mixture was treated in EtOH reflux condition at the appropriate time according Table 1. After completion of the reaction, the obtained precipitate was centrifuged. The obtained percipate was dissolved in PEG to separate the catalyst using a centrifuge. Water was added to the solution. The obtained precipitate filtered off and was washed several times with cold EtOH (Scheme 2). Results and discussion Catalyst preparation strategy Hydrogen-bonding catalysts have been explored for their ease of design and synthesis based on green chemistry [58,59]. In continuation of our research on the synthesis and application of catalysts with urea and thiourea moieties [60–64], herein we synthesized bimetallic-MOFs with urea functional groups and hydrogen bonding ability [65–68]. First, we synthesized a metal-organic framework (MOF) based on two metals, iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) via the hydrothermal method. MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 has unique properties due to the use of two metals. Enhanced catalytic stability and performance are among the features that can be simultaneously observed in the reported bimetallic-MOFs catalysts, due to the synergistic properties of two metals. We post-modified the above-mentioned metal-organic framework (MOF) with phenyl isocyanate for creating urea functional groups and producing its corresponding H-bond catalyst (Scheme 1 ). SEM, EDX, Elemental-mapping, XRD, BET/BJH, TG/DTA and FT-IR techniques were used to investigate the structure of the catalyst. Multicomponent reactions are very important in the production of organic compounds with a wide diversity. Therefore, the above bimetallic-MOFs were used in the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines with pyrazolo, henna and indole moieties under EtOH reflux condition. Due to the fact that this type of hydrogen bond catalyst acts selectively and can have both acid and base roles. Therefore, very good results have been obtained for the synthesis of target compounds. We thoroughly investigated the structures of the products using melting point, FT-IR, 1H NMR and 13C NMR techniques (Scheme 2 ). The stereochemistry and mechanism of the synthesized products were also investigated. For this purpose, by studying the mechanism of the reaction, it was observed that the products prepared with 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine are stopped at the stage of dihydropyran formation and the reaction does not proceed towards ring aromatization, while the structures prepared with 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-3-amine were converted into the corresponding aromatic pyridine rings. Therefore, the process of aromatization and pyridine ring formation was carried out via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation (CVABO). Characterization FT-IR spectra of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 and MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR were showed in Fig. 1 . The synthesized H-bond catalyst (MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR) clearly shows an increase in phenyl isocyanate groups and the formation of urea structures, which is in close agreement with previous reports [36]. The peaks in the range 3365–3472 cm-1 indicate stretching vibrations NH2 group in the MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2. The peak in region 1658 cm-1 is associated with stretching vibrations of the carboxyl functional groups in bimetallic-MOFs. Also, the absorption bands in the regions of 460 and 566 cm-1 are related to the formation ligand-metal bonding formation (Fe-O and Co-O), which indicates the successful synthesis of bonds in the desired catalyst structure. Also, the NH peaks related to urea are well added in the region of 3100–3500 cm-1. By comparing the FT-IR spectra of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 and MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, we find that the MOF structure remains stable after adding phenyl isocyanate and forming urea on it. To investigate the crystal structure of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, the above catalyst was analyzed together with MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 using XRD analysis. Investigations have revealed that the crystal pattern of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 agrees well with previous reports [56]. Comparing the XRD pattern of two stages in the course of synthesis shows that the original bimetallic-MOF crystal structure is preserved after the addition of phenyl isocyanate and the formation of urea moiety on it. This result shows the stability of the MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 structure and confirms the results of FT-IR analysis (Fig. 2 ). The morphologies of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 and MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR were studied by scanning electron microscope (SEM) analysis. As seen in Fig. 3 (a, b) the morphology of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-NH2 is spindle-shaped. Even after synthesizing MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR with increasing phenyl isocyanate, the morphology of the MOF did not change which indicates the stability of the catalyst (Fig. 3c, d). The high yield of synthesized products (75–90%) can be due to the proper morphology, structure and activity of the presented catalyst. This type of suitable morphology provides a suitable substrate for the reaction. To further investigate the structure of the catalyst, MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR was analyzed using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) and SEM elemental-mapping analysis (Fig. 4 a, b). It has been confirmed that the elements iron (Fe), cobalt (Co), oxygen (O), nitrogen (N) and carbon (C) are present in the structure of the catalyst. SEM elemental-mapping analysis (Fig. 4b) clearly shows the uniformity of the distribution of the elements. The surface area and pore size of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR were measured by N2 -adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 5 a). According to the results obtained for MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, the surface area was calculated as 10.4 m2g-1 based on BET equation. The total pore volume 0.144 cm3g-1 was obtained. Using the BJH diagram shown in Fig. 5b, the pore size distribution for the desired catalyst was obtained. The average pore diameter of the catalyst is 55.2 nm. To verify the stability of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst, thermogravimetric analysis (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were investigated. As shown in Fig. 6 , we see a two-step reduction. The first weight loss at temperatures below 100 °C is associated with the removal of solvents (organic and aqueous) which were used in the course of synthesis and the second weight loss is observed at 250 °C. This is to demonstrate the decomposition of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR. Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) data show that the abovementioned catalyst can be used up to 250 °C. Catalytic activity After the synthesis and identification of the structure of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst, this catalyst was used in the synthesis of new pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline derivatives with pyrazolo, henna and indole moieties. For the synthesis of the abovementioned products, 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine (1 mmol, 0.198 g), henna (1 mmol, 0.174 g) and 4-bromobenzaldehyde (1 mmol, 0.185 g) were selected as a model reaction. The optimization data is shown in Fig. 7 . According to the data in diagram a, we investigated the model of reaction in different solvents such as H2O, CH2Cl2, CHCl3, EtOH, MeOH, DMF, CH3CN, toluene, ethyl acetate and n-hexane, as well as in solvent-free conditions. The best efficiency and the least side products were related to performing the reaction under EtOH reflux. Next, we examined the optimal conditions at different temperatures and amounts of catalyst. On the basis of the obtained results from the refluxing EtOH using 10 mg of catalyst was the best condition for conducting the reaction. The obtained results show that values higher or lower than the optimal values obtained do not improve the reaction conditions. After determining the optimal conditions of the reaction, the MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR was used to synthesize a wide range of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines including various aldehydes via electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups (Table 1 ). As can be seen in Table 1, MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, which is a new hydrogen bond catalyst, has a high ability to prepare a variety of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline derivatives compounds with high efficiency. Also, the high speed of the reaction and the short duration of the reaction are the major advantages of the presented catalyst, which makes it suitable for organic synthesis. In the proposed mechanism, aldehyde is activated by MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst. On the other hand, the activated henna by one of the urea moiety at the presented catalyst, reacts with aldehyde carbonyl group. Then a water molecule is removed and intermediate (I) is created. In the following, via a Michael addition of 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine to intermediate (I), intermediate (II) is created. In the next step, intermediate (II) is converted to intermediate (III) under the influence of tautomerization process. In continued, with the attack of the amine group on the carbonyl group, intramolecular cyclization occurs. Releasing another water molecule from intramolecular cyclization, 1,4-dihydropyridine (intermediate (IV), is obtained. Finally, 1,4- dihydropyridines (IV) is converted to the corresponding pyridine derivatives through a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation (CVABO) mechanism and releases a molecule of hydrogen (-H2) and/or hydrogen peroxide (-H2O2) [29,35]. It was observed that the products prepared with 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine are stopped at the stage of dihydropyran formation and the reaction does not proceed towards ring aromatization, while the structures prepared with 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1-phenyl-1H-pyrazol-3-amine were converted into the corresponding aromatic pyridine rings (Scheme 3 ). In the next investigation, in order to find out the efficiency of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as a new porous bimetallic H-bond catalyst, we applied the model of reaction including 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine (1 mmol, 0.198 g), henna (1 mmol, 0.174 g) and 4-bromobenzaldehyde (1 mmol, 0.185 g) with different types of inorganic and organic catalysts under the mentioned optimal reaction. The results obtained are categorized in Table 2 . According to the results of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR, which is a new hydrogen bond catalyst, it has the highest production efficiency of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinoline products. As can be seen, it has a shorter reaction time than other organic and inorganic catalysts. The recycle and reuse ability of the described catalyst was also investigated. The results of Fig. 8 show that MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR can be recycled and reused up to 6 times, without significant changes in catalytic activity. The FT-IR and XRD analysis of the recovered catalyst were studied. The obtained results show that after recovery, the catalyst has good stability. Therefore, the presented catalyst is a good candidate for the synthesis of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines. Hot filtration test The catalytic activity of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR in the production of pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines derivatives was investigated by hot filtration test. For this purpose, the model reaction involving 5-(1H-indol-3-yl)-1H-pyrazol-3-amine (1 mmol, 0.198 g), henna (1 mmol, 0.174 g) and 4-bromobenzaldehyde (1 mmol, 0.185 g) was carried out in the presence of MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR (10 mg) as a hydrogen bond catalyst. The above reaction was stopped after 1 h and a 55% yield was obtained. In another container, the model reaction was repeated and after 1 h the reaction was stopped and the catalyst was isolated from the reaction mixture (according to the catalytic reaction section). Then ethanol was added to the above mixture and the model reaction was allowed to stir for another 2 h under the same optimal conditions. After determining the efficiency at this time, the results showed that there was no improvement in the reaction efficiency. An ICP-OES test was also conducted to investigate this matter further. The results showed that 0.51 × 10–3 mol/g of iron and 0.05 × 10–3 of cobalt remained in the product. Therefore, it seems that the reaction proceeds with little efficiency after removing the catalyst. Conclusion In this article, we described the design and synthesis of a hydrogen-bonding catalyst based on bimetallic-MOF using two metals, iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co). The presence of iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) metals provide synergistic properties such as catalyst performance and stability, which are important reasons for choosing these two metals in the desired MOF structure. This report presents a new functional class of porous composites based on bimetallic organic frameworks (bimetallic-MOFs). Our main goal in this report is to expand task-specific and designable catalytic systems. The synthesized catalyst was used in multicomponent reactions to prepare pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines with pyrazolo, henna, and indole moieties. The major advantages of the above research work include clean synthesis based on green chemistry principles, easy separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture, high reaction rate and efficiency in the synthesis target product, and avoidance of by-products. coredata.dc:description: Bimetallic organic frameworks (bimetallic-MOFs) are considered promising catalysts due to their tunable pores, strength, and high catalytic performance. Here, a bimetallic-MOF-based on iron (Fe) and cobalt (Co) metals was designed, synthesized and characterized. Next, the synthesized bimetallic-MOFs were post-modified with phenyl isocyanate to create urea moieties that are susceptible to hydrogen bonding (H-bond) catalytic activities. Various techniques such as SEM, XRD, BET/BJH, FT-IR, TGA/DTA, EDX and elemental-mapping were used to approve the structure of the synthesized catalyst. MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR acts as an H-bond catalyst in the multi-component reaction to form pyrazolo[3,4-b]quinolines via appropriate sections with medicinal properties. The features of using MIL-88B(Fe2/Co)-UR as an H-bond catalyst are increased efficiency, decreased reaction time and reusability of the catalyst.
